title.content: Why did 16 people die in the Great Fire of London?

clue1.content: About 13,200 houses, nearly 90 parish churches, and nearly 50 livery company halls were burnt down.

clue2.content: The strong easterly wind kept the fire burning.

clue3.content: The fire began at night when everybody was asleep.

clue4.content: Houses were pulled down to stop the fire spreading, but wood and rubbish were left lying in the street.

clue5.content: The buckets were made of wood and leather.

clue6.content: The fire started in Pudding Lane.

clue7.content: Sparks from the Baker's burning house fell on hay and straw at the Star Inn.

clue8.content: The Baker lived in Pudding Lane.

clue9.content: Riverfront warehouses were bursting full of oil, tallow and other combustible goods.

clue10.content: The Baker forgot to turn off his oven.

clue11.content: The fire destroyed about four-fifths of the city, or more than 430 acres.

clue12.content: The buildings caught fire very easily.

clue13.content: On Wednesday night the wind hushed and the fire burned gently.

clue14.content: Lots of people spent time saving their things instead of trying to stop the fire spreading.

clue15.content: Hundreds of rats lived in Pudding Lane.

clue16.content: The people tried to put the fire out with buckets of water.

clue17.content: The Baker's maid was the first victim of the Great Fire.

clue18.content: The Baker said that he thought he had put out his oven, but embers from the fire set light to nearby firewood.

clue19.content: Thomas Farrinor was Baker to King Charles II
